FY1920.Q31: The Atmospheric Sciences Research Center (ASRC), of the State University of New York at Albany, was established on February 16, 1961 by the Board of Trustees of the State University of New York, as a SUNY system-wide resource for developing and administering programs in basic and applied sciences related to the atmospheric environment. ASRC's world-class researchers study the physical and chemical processes of the atmosphere, land, and water systems, and apply that knowledge to explore the interaction of chemical, physical, geological and biological processes that impact our environment. Through technology transfer and collaboration with state, federal and industrial partners, ASRC enhances New York State's scientific capacity and infrastructure, while advancing the quality of life and economic wellbeing of its citizens.
FY1920.Q41: ASRC's annual operating budget is derived from IFR from sponsored funds. Most of our payroll is provided by state funding. Any gaps in payroll are covered by our IFR accounts.

FY1920.Q81_4:
Supported by an ESD grant, the xCITE (ExTREME Collaboration, Innovation, & TEchnology) laboratory was established in Spring 2019. This is a state-of-the-art data and visual analytics center that is connecting atmospheric science research and applications with emerging technologies – such as artificial intelligence (A.I.) and machine learning, data analytics, virtual reality, and application development. 

See: https://www.albany.edu/news-center/news/look-inside-xcite-laboratory 

•The xCITE laboratory, directed by Dr Kara Sulia, been involved in several significant grants that exploit AI:
•EDD/NYSERDA ($475K):  Funded  (Sulia/Bassill)
•DOE ($336K): Funded. (Sulia)
•NSF AI-Center ($2.4M): Funded Aug 2020 (Thorncroft/Sulia)
•NIH ($2.3M): Submitted, (Thorncroft, Sulia, Freedman, Bassill….in collaboration with  Wadsworth and SPH)

This directly addresses the first priority included in ASRC’s 2019/20 Action Plan that was concerned with exploiting and elevating the xCITE laboratory.
FY1920.Q81_5:
Dr. Sara Lance received an NSF Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) award from NSF ($684K) to study the chemistry taking place in clouds around Whiteface Mountain. In addition to supporting basic science it will also support a chemistry/climate summer camp serving students from local school districts in the Albany area. See: https://www.albany.edu/news/93279.php

This directly contributes to the second priority included in the 2019/20 Action Plan for ASRC that was concerned with elevating the facility and science taking place at the Whiteface Mountain Field Station.
FY1920.Q81_6:
In collaboration with Dr.'s Richard Perez and Jeff Freedman a whitepaper was created that provides a vision for how weather information, including the NYS Mesonet, will help NY State achieve its 100% renewables goal by 2040. Efforts are ongoing to promote this with the State and the public. Interviews were also given on “Capitol Tonight” on Spectrum News and for the “Capital Pressroom”, WCNY. ASRC leads a number of funded research projects that deal with renewable energy. 

A major multi-partner DOE grant for around $10M was led and submitted by Dr Jeff Freedman, concerned with a field experiment focused on off-shore wind. 

This directly contributes to the third priority included in the 2019/20 Action Plan for ASRC concerned with elevating and promoting ASRC expertise in renewable energy.
FY1920.Q91: Establish and Promote Weather-AI and Data Analytics capabilities at ASRC building on the newly established xCITE laboratory– Specifically: (1) Promote usage of the xCITE laboratory in ASRC, DAES and the University campus in the area of Artificial intelligence and Machine Learning. Measurable: number of users. (2) Initiate a campus Weather AI/ML group to exchange ideas, promote research and coordinate research proposals. Measurable: number of members in the group (3) Secure additional external funding in the Weather-AI and Data analytics domain. Measurable: booked research support (4) Increase exposure of the xCITE facility and related activities through publications, conference/workshop demonstrations; website; logos, media and marketing etc: Measurable: Numbers of papers, presentations, public awareness.

(iii)The ASRC Whiteface Mountain Field Station has been working to improve the infrastructure at the summit observatory over the past year. We started out 2020 with plans for upgrades to the observatory including structural repairs as well as electrical upgrades and a roof replacement project. These plans were to coincide with the 50th anniversary of the observatory and also to predicate deployment of several new instruments by Dr. Sara Lance. Several meetings were held with Facilities Management staff as well as the design team from CSARCH. The work was put out to bid in April 2020. Only one bid was received and was determined to be too high. Due to financial constraints related to the COVID-19 pandemic it was decided that the scope of the project should be reduced and put back out to bid. We decided to focus on the most urgent need which is the roof replacement. However even with the reduced scope of work we were informed that there were not funds available to move forward this year. The current plan is to have staff from the UALBANY roofing shop come up on Wednesday 9/16/2020 to attempt to refasten the existing roof to get us through the winter. We are hopeful that a more permanent fix will be forthcoming in the near future. (M3)

(iv)The EIP search was initiated. (M4)

FY1920.Q123:
(i)Performed visual quality screening of New York State Mesonet (NYSM) soil moisture observational records at 119 stations. Identified data quality issues related to frozen soil conditions, service disruptions, as well as site- and soil moisture retrieval-specific soil type disparities. These issues were reported to the NYSM, which addressed the frozen soil and disruption effects in a March 2020 reprocessed release of the full NYSM soil moisture and temperature record (November 2015–December 2019). Soil type corrections will be left to the discretion of the end-user. (M1)

(ii)Demonstrated added-value of NASA Soil Moisture Active Passive satellite-derived soil moisture data assimilation in a short-term weather forecast context in conditionally-accepted article in Monthly Weather Review (M1): 

Ferguson, C.R., S. Agrawal, M. Beauharnois, G. Xia, D.A. Burrows and L. Bosart (2020), Satellite soil moisture assimilation for improved forecasts of Great Plains low-level jet ramp events, Mon. Wea. Rev..

(iii)Development of a mesonet--National Water Model-satellite soil moisture data fusion approach is ongoing in collaboration with Princeton University and Duke University collaborators. Once proven, the approach will be integrated in the form of an observational operator in the U.S. multi-agency Joint Effort for Data Assimilation Integration (JEDI) system.  (M1)

(iv)A proposal was submitted to NASA to develop dynamic vegetation root-groundwater interactions within the National Water Model.  (M1)

(v)A proposal to NASA to extend the SMAP soil moisture data assimilation work was not selected for funding but will be resubmitted in some form. (M1)

(vi)Efforts remain ongoing to develop collaborations with the Canal Corporation, USGS and the NE River Forecasting Center. USGS is currently incorporating one NYS Mesonet station into its ice-jamming monitoring efforts. (M2)

(vii)	A proposal is currently planned for submission in the coming year that is based on SAFER. Partners currently include ASRC, DAES, CEHC and Penn State. (M3)

FY1920.FY2021Mission: The Atmospheric Sciences Research Center (ASRC), of the State University of New York at Albany, was established on February 16, 1961 by the Board of Trustees of the State University of New York, as a SUNY system-wide resource for developing and administering programs in basic and applied sciences related to the atmospheric environment. ASRC's world-class researchers study the physical and chemical processes of the atmosphere, land, and water systems, and apply that knowledge to explore the interaction of chemical, physical, geological and biological processes that impact our environment. Through technology transfer and collaboration with state, federal and industrial partners, ASRC enhances New York State's scientific capacity and infrastructure, while advancing the quality of life and economic wellbeing of its citizens.
FY1920.FY2021Vision: The vision for the center in the coming year is to maintain our traditional strengths but also to seek out and strengthen strategic collaborations in key research areas including two areas that will get renewed focus this year: (i) Boundary Layer and Air Quality and (ii) Aerosol-Cloud-Precipitation-Weather-Climate Interactions.

FY1920.FY1920Action3: Specifically: (1) Start the EIP renewable energy scientist hiring process - subject to University permission.  (2) Secure additional external funding to support this work (e.g. NOAA, NSF, NYSERDA.  (3) Build R&D relationships on the perfect forecast/firm power generation concepts via COE, EdESLR. (4) Expand ASRC’s renewable energy group’s R&D and collaborative partnerships in offshore wind.  (5) Promote ASRC’s research portfolio in renewables through publications, presentations and outreach to public and State Government.
FY1920.FY1920Goal4: Expand ASRC’s portfolio in hydrology research including exploitation of NYS Mesonet observationsExpand ASRC’s portfolio in hydrology research including exploitation of NYS Mesonet observations
FY1920.FY1920Action4: Specifically: (1) To promote and establish research that contributes to improving NOAA’s National Water Model through data assimilation efforts that includes mesonet and satellite data; integrating the NWM products into U.S. Drought Monitor and improving representation of groundwater-streamflow interactions.  (2) Enhance relationships and collaborations with hydrological groups in NY State including Canal Corporation (NYPA), USGS and NOAA’s NE River Forecasting Center.  (3) Secure funding for all or part of the research described in the NSF STC Pre-proposal “SAFER” that deals with user-driven adaptive modeling of flood risk.
FY1920.FY1920Goal5: Establish an Undergraduate Recruitment Plan taking advantage of Weather-Climate Enterprise Assets,
FY1920.FY1920Action5: Specifically: (1) Working with NYS Mesonet, COE and DAES, establish and implement a recruitment plan that takes advantage of the presence of NYS Mesonet stations across the State.  (2) Include in this strategy a Media and Marketing effort to promote the Weather and Climate Enterprise across the State.

FY2021.Q31: The Atmospheric Sciences Research Center (ASRC), of the State University of New York at Albany, was established on February 16, 1961 by the Board of Trustees of the State University of New York, as a SUNY system-wide resource for developing and administering programs in basic and applied sciences related to the atmospheric environment. ASRC's world-class researchers study the physical and chemical processes of the atmosphere, land, and water systems, and apply that knowledge to explore the interaction of chemical, physical, geological and biological processes that impact our environment. Through technology transfer and collaboration with state, federal and industrial partners, ASRC enhances New York State's scientific capacity and infrastructure, while advancing the quality of life and economic wellbeing of its citizens.
FY2021.Q32: The vision for the center in the coming year is to maintain our traditional strengths but also to seek out and strengthen strategic collaborations in key research areas including two areas that will get renewed focus this year: (i) Boundary Layer and Air Quality and (ii) Aerosol-Cloud-Precipitation-Weather-Climate Interactions.
FY2021.Q41:
People:
ASRC’s 14 faculty and 9 staff (including one full-time staff person at Whiteface Mountain) are supported by UAlbany. Over the past five years, ASRC’s payroll expenditures totaled $9,530,608 – an average of $1,906,121 per year. One full-time research facilitator and one part-time IT support person are supported by the VPR.

Post-docs, research scientists, visiting scholars, graduate students, and undergraduate students are primarily paid from research grants; some are supported from start-up funds provided to SUNY2020 faculty. Most ASRC faculty are on 9-month academic year appointments and are paid summer salary from research grants or start-up funds.

OTPS:
ASRC’s operations, including operations at the UAlbany location and at Whiteface
Mountain, are covered by IFR reserves and IFR revenue recovered from sponsored programs. Over the past five years, ASRC’s OTPS expenditures at the Albany location have totaled $257,588, an average of $51,517 per year. With annual telephone charges of almost $19,000 per year, OTPS expenses at ASRC average to about $32,500 per year. The Whiteface location’s OTPS expenditures over the last five years total $71,120, an average of $14,224 per year.

A few faculty members have legacy IFR accounts to cover some OTPS expenses such as Verizon Wireless.

Strategic Investment:
We have about $206,800 in cash to spend on the state-side.

On the RF side there is a legacy overhead recovery account primarily used in support of our RF p-card program as the initial source to pay the Bank of America bill monthly; expenses are then moved to the appropriate sponsored award through a reconciliation process. ASRC has received overhead recovery from the VPR to be used to grow research activity at ASRC. This account has a balance of $11,600.

Events:
ASRC has both UAlbany Foundation funds in the Ray Falconer Endowment and UAS (Auxiliary Services) funds to support lectures and colloquies.
